Distinguished Harvard Lecture

Instant Gratification, Multiple Selves, and Self-Control: How to Control Your Selves

Thursday, December 2, 2010 - 4pm-5:30pm

Yenching Auditorium, 2 Divinity Avenue

Hosted by Mind/Brain/Behavior Co-Directors Alfonso Caramazza and Albert Galaburda

: : :


Harvard University and the Mind/Brain/Behavior Initiative are pleased to announce their 2010-2011 MBB Distinguished Harvard Lecture. The special lecturer will be David I. Laibson, Robert I. Goldman Professor of Economics. This talk is open to the public.

People frequently fail to live up to their good intentions. New Year's resolutions, diets, exercise regimes, budgets, and self-imposed deadlines are reliably broken. Professor Laibson will explain why these failures arise, presenting a range of laboratory and field evidence, including neuroimaging experiments. Professor Laibson will discuss strategies for committing oneself to one's long-run goals and thereby overcoming the desire for instant gratification. The analysis will trace out implications for personal decision-making and government policy-making.
